title: 108_s2202
content:
The "Bring Our Children Home Act" allows for jurisdiction over competing state custody orders and establishes a national registry of custody orders. The Attorney General will establish a national child custody and visitation registry containing certified copies of court determinations, information on pending proceedings, and details on Hague Convention cases. Cooperation with Federal and State courts is required. The Attorney General will provide financial and technical assistance for a national child custody and visitation registry accessible to courts, law enforcement, and custody contestants. SEC. 4. DETENTION OF CHILDREN LISTED AS MISSING.

Law enforcement officers may hold a missing child for up to 24 hours or until a custody decision is made based on the National Crime Information Center's Missing Person File.

SEC. 5. INTERNATIONAL CHILD ABDUCTION REMEDIES. Legal Assistance for Victims of Parental Kidnapping Grants program provides funding to legal services providers for direct legal services in parental kidnapping cases under the International Child Abduction Remedies Act. The Central Authority provides training and technical assistance to recipients of funds to improve their capacity to offer legal assistance. The Legal Services Corporation may use funds to represent aliens in proceedings under the Convention, regardless of their residency status. Section 8(b) of the International Child Abduction Remedies Act is amended to exempt individuals from court costs. The Child Abduction Remedies Act is amended to specify that no court costs may be assessed on a petitioner seeking the return of a child in the United States. Petitioners may be responsible for legal counsel, court costs, and travel expenses, with exceptions outlined in the Act. The International Child Abduction Remedies Act is amended to specify that no court costs may be assessed on a petitioner seeking the return of a child in the United States. The United States Central Authority is responsible for encouraging the designation of specific courts for Convention cases and providing technical assistance and training as needed. The United States Central Authority is responsible for providing training on laws related to parental kidnapping to judges, lawyers, and law students. Funds may be allocated for training programs, and recipients must report on the programs. The Federal Judicial Center is required to include information on continuing education and training programs for judges. The Federal Judicial Center is responsible for training programs on laws related to parental kidnapping for judges. This includes information on Hague Convention, International Child Abduction Remedies Act, and other relevant Federal statutes. Materials are prepared to support this training. SEC. 6. REPORTS RELATING TO INTERNATIONAL CHILD ABDUCTION. The Secretary of State must provide an annual report to Congress on progress in negotiating bilateral treaties related to international child abduction with non-Hague Convention countries. Additionally, there must be a report on human rights practices, including efforts to prohibit international child abduction in each country. The annual report to Congress must include information on efforts to prohibit international child abduction and respect custody rights in each country. The Attorney General, with input from the Secretary of State, must annually report to Congress on extradition cases related to violations of Section 1204 of Title 18, United States Code. Support for Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act. The Attorney General will provide support for the adoption and implementation of the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act (UCCJEA) by states through grants and contracts. This support includes promoting adoption, providing training to legal professionals and judges, and offering guidance and funding for enforcement. The Attorney General supports states in enforcing custody and visitation provisions of the UCCJEA to expedite the process. The Federal Judicial Center's education programs include training on laws related to parental kidnapping, such as the Hague Convention and International Child Abduction Remedies Act. Additionally, supervised visitation centers are utilized in situations involving the risk of parental kidnapping under the Safe Havens for Children Pilot Program. Section 1301(a) of the Violence Against Women Act of 2000 is amended to include the risk of parental kidnapping along with domestic violence and stalking.
